skill.name: mobile-ios-design
skill.description: Master iOS Human Interface Guidelines and SwiftUI patterns for building native iOS apps. Use when designing iOS interfaces, implementing SwiftUI views, or ensuring apps follow Apple's design principles.
skill.summary: Provides iOS Human Interface Guidelines and SwiftUI patterns for building polished, native iOS applications that follow Apple design principles.
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing iOS design guidelines and SwiftUI code examples. All static findings are false positives: markdown code blocks (```swift) were misidentified as shell backticks, Swift code patterns triggered crypto/recon heuristics, and Apple documentation URLs were flagged as hardcoded URLs. No executable code, network calls, credential handling, or shell commands present.

content.value_statement: Building iOS apps requires following Apple Human Interface Guidelines and modern SwiftUI patterns. This skill provides comprehensive references for creating polished, accessible, and platform-native iOS interfaces.
actual_capabilities: Provide iOS Human Interface Guidelines principles for clarity, deference, and depth
Generate SwiftUI code for navigation patterns including NavigationStack, TabView, and NavigationSplitView
Create adaptive layouts for iPhone and iPad using size classes and grid systems
Implement SF Symbols, semantic colors, and Dynamic Type for platform-native appearance
Design accessible interfaces with VoiceOver support and accessibility modifiers
Build toolbar patterns, search integration, and haptic feedback implementations
limitations: Does not generate complete Xcode projects or iOS app scaffolding
Does not provide Swift coding beyond UI and design patterns
Does not integrate with Apple APIs or services beyond documentation references
Does not validate design decisions against app store review guidelines

use_cases.title: Build iOS App Interfaces
use_cases.description: Generate SwiftUI code for creating iOS app interfaces that follow Apple Human Interface Guidelines, including navigation, layouts, and system integration.

use_cases.title: Refactor Existing UI Code
use_cases.description: Modernize legacy UIKit code to SwiftUI, or improve existing SwiftUI implementations to better follow platform conventions.
use_cases.target_user: Developers maintaining or upgrading iOS apps

use_cases.title: Learn iOS Design Patterns
use_cases.description: Study reference examples for common iOS design patterns including navigation, lists, forms, accessibility, and visual feedback.
use_cases.target_user: Developers new to iOS or SwiftUI

prompt_templates.title: Create Navigation Pattern
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a SwiftUI navigation pattern using NavigationStack for an iOS app that shows a list of items. Include programmatic navigation and state persistence.
prompt_templates.scenario: Building a navigation structure for an iOS app

prompt_templates.title: Design Adaptive Layout
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an adaptive SwiftUI layout that uses size classes to show a single-column grid on iPhone and a three-column grid on iPad. Include safe area handling.
prompt_templates.scenario: Building responsive layouts for multiple iOS device sizes

prompt_templates.title: Implement Accessible Components
prompt_templates.prompt: Create accessible SwiftUI components including VoiceOver support, Dynamic Type scaling, and semantic color usage for automatic dark mode.

prompt_templates.title: Build Form with Validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a settings form in SwiftUI with text fields, toggles, pickers, and custom validation. Include @AppStorage for persistence and proper iOS form styling.
prompt_templates.scenario: Building user preference screens in iOS apps

output_examples.input: Create a SwiftUI card component with SF Symbol, title, description, and accessibility support
output: A horizontal card with icon, title text, description text, and chevron indicator
Uses semantic fonts (.headline, .subheadline) for Dynamic Type support
Applies semantic colors (.primary, .secondary) for light/dark mode

output_examples.input: Design a tab-based navigation structure with four tabs
output: TabView with Home, Search, Notifications, and Profile tabs
Each tab uses Label with systemImage for consistent SF Symbols
Proper tag and selection state management
NavigationStack embedded within each tab for nested navigation

best_practices: Use semantic colors (.primary, .secondary, .background) instead of hardcoded colors for automatic light/dark mode support
Apply semantic fonts (.body, .headline, .title) instead of fixed sizes to support Dynamic Type
Include accessibility modifiers (.accessibilityLabel, .accessibilityHint) on all interactive elements
anti_patterns: Using fixed frame sizes or hardcoded padding values instead of flexible layouts and safe area insets
Ignoring size classes when designing for both iPhone and iPad form factors
Skipping accessibility testing or using fixed text instead of semantic fonts

faq.question: What iOS versions does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill focuses on modern iOS patterns (iOS 16+) including NavigationStack, but also includes legacy patterns like NavigationLink for compatibility with earlier versions.

faq.question: Does this skill generate complete app projects?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides design patterns, component examples, and guidelines. You will need to integrate the generated code into your own Xcode project.

faq.question: How do I handle deep linking in iOS apps?
faq.answer: Use NavigationStack with NavigationPath to build deep linking support. Append destinations programmatically and handle URL schemes in your app delegate.

faq.question: What accessibility features should I implement?
faq.answer: Include .accessibilityLabel(), .accessibilityHint(), .accessibilityValue() on interactive views. Support Dynamic Type with semantic fonts and test with VoiceOver enabled.

faq.question: How do I support both iPhone and iPad layouts?
faq.answer: Use @Environment(\.horizontalSizeClass) to detect compact vs regular size classes. Create different column counts and layouts for each class using GridItem with .adaptive or .flexible.

faq.question: Does this skill cover UIKit or only SwiftUI?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on SwiftUI patterns. For UIKit patterns, you would need a separate skill or reference Apple's UIKit documentation.
